First of all, I am a huge Indiana Jones fan and this game made me want to watch it all again. The graphics, easter eggs and puzzles were amusing. 38637420.review:
I do not do a lot of reviews, but wanted to rave about how amazing this game is! Growing up I loved Harrison Ford in movies like Star Wars and Indiana Jones. My dad was big into PC gaming as I was growing up so he owned this game. I started to play it and instantly fell in love with it. First of all, you have to complete tasks in a puzzle-like way. It really makes you listen and remember what the characters say in the game in order to figure out what you have to do next. Then, it is very entertaining according to what happens, what characters say, and how they say it. You have the option to drive a car, air balloon, or submarine based on the path you choose. At one point in the game you can either continue on with the main mission with this woman named Sophia in two scenarios or one without her. Lastly, I love the 90s feel this game gives me with the pixelated objects and people and ASWD controls. It is an overall excellent game with all of my favorite aspects. Playing it as an adult is just as good as I remember.

38233038.review:
Der Mann mit der Peitsche und dem Hut kehrt zurück und beweist erneut, dass Archäologie nicht langweilig sein muss. Diesmal ohne Filmvorlage, muss Indiana Jones verhindern, dass die bösen Nazis in Atlantis zu den Übermenschen werden, die sie gerne gewesen wären.

Das Spiel beginnt mit einem interaktiven Intro, in dem man in der Rolle von "Indiana Jones" ein altes Artefakt in seinem Heimat-Universität suchen soll. Das hört sich eher langweilig an, ist aber zum Brüllen komisch, wenn man sieht, dass der Abenteurer, der sonst jede Falle in verborgenen Tempeln umgehen oder entschärfen kann, in seinem eigenen College von einer "Falle" in die nächste tappt, und dabei einen Ort der Verwüstung hinterlässt.

Das Artefakt entpuppt sich als Schlüssel für eine Figur... nur blöd, dass der seriöse blonde Herr in Indys Büro sich ebenfalls als etwas unfreundlich entpuppt. Die Spuren der Nazis führen Indy zu seiner Ex-Kollegin Sophia Hapgood, die mit Betrügereien ihren wissenschaftlichen Ruf und Indys Vertrauen verspielt hat. Auf der Suche nach dem "Buch des Hippokrates" fliegen die beiden nach Island, in die Karibik und zurück an die Ostküste der USA. Sobald sie das Buch haben, ist der entscheidende Punkt des Spieles erreicht, an dem man sich für einen von drei Lösungswegen entscheiden muss: den Team-Modus (mit Sophia), den Rätsel-Modus und den Action-Modus. Abhängig von der Lösung des ersten Rätsels schlägt Sophia zwar einen Modus vor, man kann sich aber auch anders entscheiden.

Ab hier beginnen drei unterschiedliche Handlungsstränge, die erst gegen Ende des Spieles wieder zusammenlaufen. Einige Locations besucht man in allen 3 Spielmodi, andere nur bei einem Modus. Außerdem sind viele Rätsel trotz gleicher Locations in den verschiedenen Modi anders (man findet andere Gegenstände und trifft andere Personen). Wer Indy 4 nur einmal durchgespielt hat, hat mindestens ein Drittel des Spiels verpasst.

Wie beim Vorgänger gibt es auch bei "Indiana Jones and the Fate of Atlantis" Punkte für jedes gelöste Rätsel, die im IQ (Indy-Quotienten) festgehalten werden. Da es auch innerhalb eines Lösungsweges mehrere Lösungen für manche Rätsel gibt, müsste man für die volle Punktzahl das Spiel mindestens sechsmal durchspielen, um alle IQ-Punkte zu erreichen.

Indy 4 ist nach meiner Meinung immer noch das beste Adventure aller Zeiten:
- die Rätsel sind durchweg logisch
- der Wiederspielwert ist durch verschiedene Lösungswege und IQ-Punkte sehr hoch
- die Bedienung ist Dank dem bewährten SCUMM-System sehr komfortabel
- die Grafik ist für VGA- und Amiga-Verhältnisse vom allerfeinsten und kann sich heute noch sehen lassen
- das iMuse-Sound-System sorgte dafür, dass die Hintergrundmusik sich an die jeweilige Spielsituation anpasste

Im Abspann von Indy 4 wird angekündigt, dass es ein Wiedersehen mit Indiana Jones geben wird ... als jüngeren Mann. Auf das versprochene Young-Indy-Adventure warte ich noch heute. :(

Of all the LucasArts SCUMM engine games, this is the pinacle of their efforts. This game offered players 3 different ways to beat the game, based on your preference for play, harder puzzles, teamwork (dialogue and NPC control), or punching people out. While the story arc remained largely the same, the three routes did offer some variety and an excuse to replay this great story.

LucasArts games have been seeing remasters lately. This gem will hopefully get a new coat of polish, along with the slightly more obtuse but no less nostalgic-inducing Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade puzzle game.

36493757.review:
Le seule bonne raison d'acheter ce jeu est la nostalgie !

Certes quelques bons points sont à noter : re-jouabilité (trois "chemins" possibles), ambiance, humour et univers Indiana Jones bien restitués (mais sans plus), quelques phases de gameplay "arcade" originales pour le genre (ça plait ou pas), le jeu fonctionne également bien en plein écran sous windows 10 sans étirer l'image.

Cependant, si la première moitié du jeu est agréable (jusque à la sortie du sous-marin selon moi), la dernière partie est imbuvable. J'arrive habituellement à terminer ce genre de jeu en utilisant très peu la solution, mais là j'en ai abusé ! Parfois d'ailleurs pour constater que ce que j'avais en tête était la bonne solution, mais je n'étais pas dans la bonne salle, ou je n'avais pas cliqué sur le bon pixel, ou sur le bon verbe.

De plus, quelques grosses incohérences gâchent le scénario, le pire étant les nazis qui vous devancent à la sortie du sous-marin, alors que vous avez la "clef" et passez par la seule entrée (idem peu avant dans les grottes, ils sortent du chapeau alors que vous venez de vous taper une progression capillotractée, et rebelote à la fin du jeu).

Bref, du grand n'importe quoi, clairement le pire point&click à mon actif, le seul d'ailleurs finalement qui m’aie vraiment déçu.

35114170.review:
Puedes encontrar el análisis original en https://thepastisnow.net/2017/09/18/analisis-indiana-jones-and-the-fate-of-atlantis-latigos-videntes-y-cuentas-de-orichalcum/

Las aventuras de Indiana Jones siempre me han gustado independientemente de cual sea su formato, y si es en forma de aventura gráfica, mejor que mejor.

Si en la primera temporada del Blog os traje Indiana Jones y la última cruzada, para esta segunda temporada no podía dejar atrás la segunda aventura del arqueólogo del látigo para el sistema SCUMM.

En esta ocasión Indy investiga una estatuilla que ha encontrado en su despacho en el Barnet College, que un oficial nazi haciéndose pasar por el "Sr. Smith" le roba al descubrir que es un artefacto atlante. Viendo como se presenta la situación, nuestro protagonista deja pasar la oportunidad de encontrar un mundo perdido como es la Atlántida.

Sus personajes secundarios tienen mucho carácter e influencia en la historia y se convierten, sin quererlo, en personajes de peso en la aventura. Sophia Hapgood es una atractiva vidente-actriz con mucho carácter que tiene cierto vínculo y contacto con Nur-Ab-Sal, un antiguo dios de aquella civilización antigua; siendo su apellido inspirado por el de Charles Hapgood, quién fue un estudioso de la propia Atlántida. Klaus Kerner es un oficial nazi del tercer Reich muy alto y muy engreído, el perfecto antagonista para cualquiera de las aventuras de nuestro arqueólogo favorito.

Hal Barwood trabajó como guionista en películas como "Loca evasión" o "Encuentros en la tercera fase" y es el responsable de la última aventura gráfica de LucasArts que se dibujaría pixel a pixel. El bueno de Hal, que había colaborado en otros juegos de la compañía, cuido cada detalle del juego del Dr. Jones, tanto es así que hoy en día es una de las mejores aventuras de la llamada "época dorada de las aventuras gráficas" y un juego que no debes dejar pasar si te gusta el género. 

La idea para el guion del juego la sacó de un libro de misterios sin resolver de la biblioteca personal de George Lucas, en este, se hablaba de que la ciudad perdida de la Atlántida se dividía en 3 círculos concéntricos. A partir de aquí empezó el guión del juego que conocemos hoy día y que los de LucasArts se empeñaron en que se llamase "La siguiente aventura de Indy", menos mal que Hal no se rindió y se empeñó en que el juego tuviera un nombre que lo hiciera digno de una aventura de Indy (y que aventura) por lo que, tras mucho luchar, pudo dar un nombre continuista de la saga de Indiana Jones.

Es un guion original del que no se hizo película por más que los fans de la saga lo pidieron una y otra vez, e incluso cuando salió a la luz que se estaba rodando una nueva entrega de las películas, muchos pensamos que podría ser "la película del Atlantis" pero no, no fue así. No obstante si existe una serie de cómics sobre la aventura de la Atlántida.

Retomando la historia y gracias al Diálogo Perdido de Platón que Indy encuentra, obtiene algunas pistas sobre donde empezar a buscar para descubrir, un poco más tarde, la ubicación de la ciudad perdida y la llave que le dará acceso a esta civilización antigua, se trata de un sistema de combinaciones hechas con unos discos de piedra tallados.

Los puzzles del juego están muy bien llevados, son muy lógicos (al menos en su mayoría) y te meten en todo momento dentro del mundo de Indiana Jones y su relación entre los mitos y la realidad, como nos tienen acostumbrados, consiguiendo que nos sumerjamos directamente en la historia. En algunos casos la interacción de ambos personajes será obligatoria para poder avanzar, necesitaremos que Sophia negocie con algunos personajes sobre los que tiene influencia, o entretenga con preguntas a otro mientras que el Dr. Jones puede moverse a sus anchas. Si estás atrapado, no dudes en que ella puede ayudarte a dar el siguiente paso.

Y hablando sobre como relacionan la realidad con los mitos, os dejo dos imágenes de un viaje que hice a Grecia, a las ruinas de Knossos que aparecen en el juego. Cuando estuve allí y vi la similitud que había con el juego que tantas veces jugué, reviví mi infancia en aquellas ruinas y un escalofrío de nostalgia recorrió mi cuerpo. En ese momento entendí lo grande que es LucasArts y cuanto nos duele que ya no exista. Si habéis jugado, entenderéis lo que os digo.
 
En el juego podemos elegir tres caminos diferentes, uno en el que irás acompañado toda la aventura por Sophia, otro en el que irás solo con Indy utilizando el ingenio, por lo que habrá mas puzzles, y un camino en el que irás solo con Indy con mas acción, habrá mas combates y situaciones en las que usar tu habilidad como jugón será imprescindible. Pese a que los tres juegos me gustan y he disfrutado mucho con cada uno de ellos, he de reconocer que el camino con Sophia es el que más me gusta ya que, en mi humilde opinión, se asemeja mucho a una película de Indiana Jones. Tanto es así que este fue el camino que elegí para el análisis, pero os recomiendo que os hagáis también los otros dos caminos ya que no tienen desperdicio.

Tras actividades tan variadas como viajar a Montecarlo y tener una sesión de espiritismo, montar en globo en Argel o embaucar a un coleccionista de antigüedades en Las Azores, nuestros protagonistas finalmente llegaran en un submarino nazi, a la mismísima ciudad perdida de la Atlántida. Como puedes ver son todo aventuras que están muy a la altura del personaje y el mito.

El juego puedes encontrarlo en Steam o jugarlo directamente en ScummVM, para este último existe una versión en la que la comunidad fan mezclo el audio del juego con voces en CD que nunca salió en España, con la versión en castellano que llegó a nuestras tiendas.

A diferencia de otros juegos de LucasArts tanto en este como en el anterior juego de Indy, puedes morir, por lo que deberías ir guardando tu progreso de cuando en cuando. Es curioso que la compañía solo permitiera este hecho en los juegos del arqueólogo, ya que es algo que va en contra de la filosofía de la empresa pero sin embargo, vieron un valor añadido muy bueno el hecho de que Indy pudiera caer, una manera de mantener una tensión tanto en los combates como en las acciones del protagonista a lo largo del juego.

Para la parte final, independientemente del camino que hayas elegido, Sophia se une a ti para concluir la historia, ya que ella es quién tiene esa relación especial con Nur-Ab-Sal y la ciudad perdida. De nuevo el tinte cinematográfico aparece y de que manera, es uno de esos finales merecidos de toda buena historia, continuando con la calidad del juego hasta el momento y poniendo una guinda genial a la historia. Además claro está de que el hecho de "rescatar a la chica" siempre es bien recibido en estas aventuras.
 
Poco después se trabajó en una secuela para este juego que se llamaría "Indiana Jones and the Iron Phoenix", cuya trama trata sobre un Indiana Jones que, después de la segunda guerra mundial, tiene que hacerse con la piedra filosofal y viajar a América del Sur para evitar que los nazis resuciten a Hitler. El proyecto fue cancelado tras un año de desarrollo porque tenía mucha "temática nazi" y podría herir sensibilidades en un pueblo que acogía muy bien los juegos de LucasArts como era el alemán, tanto es así que para la aventura que hemos analizado hoy, las esvásticas fueron sustituidas por cruces. Aric Wilmunder (uno de los padres del sistema SCUMM) ha publicado en su web documentación relativa a este juego.

En definitiva, espectaculares gráficos en VGA 256 colores, de los mejores efectos sonoros iMUSE de la mano de Michael Z. Land (que participó en otros juegos de la compañía como "El Día del Tentáculo") y muchas horas de juego llenas de puzzles, retos y combates gracias a los tres modos de juego diferentes.

¿Y tú? ¿Acabaste muchos combates de un solo puñetazo?

¡¡¡Nos vemos pronto!!!

34458655.review:
Einer meiner ersten Kontakte mit Computerspielen abseits von Gameboy und NES überhaupt. Habe das damals zusammen mit meinem Cousin gespielt und war enorm fasziniert von der Atmosphäre und den Rätseln. Und auch heute noch kann die Atmosphäre und die schöne Pixel-Grafik durchaus überzeugen. Aus heutiger Sicht ist es auch sehr angenehm, nicht so vollgelabert zu werden wie in modernen Point-and-Klick-Adventures. Die Texte sind sehr kurz aber dennoch witzig und prägnant. Man hat nie den Eindruck, dass man zu wenig Information bekommt. Aus heutiger Sicht aber weniger angenehm fand ich ehrlich gesagt das Rätseldesign. Es ist zwar schön, dass man je nach Spielstil verschiedene Wege einschlagen kann und so auch unterschiedliche Locations besucht, aber die Umständlichkeit mancher Rätsel fand ich schon schwer nervend. In einem Höhlensystem mit diesem Kompaß-Fisch Goldkügelchen suchen, mit einer Seance einen Skeptiker von der Anwesenheit eines Gottes überzeugen (und nach jedem missglückten Versuch rennt der wieder weg) oder mit den fummeligsten Fahrzeugen aller Zeiten (Heißluftballon, U-Boot) einen bestimmten Punkt treffen - das alles zerrt schon sehr an der Geduld des (heutigen) Spielers. Dennoch war es nach so langer Zeit wieder ein Vergnügen, auch wenn ich anfangs befürchtet hatte, das spielen eines so alten Klassikers könnte meine Erinnerung daran entmystifizieren. War zum Glück aber nicht der Fall. Ein gutes Spiel überdauert auch Jahrzehnte.

Die Steam-Version ist zwar auf englisch, lässt sich aber mit einem Patch (siehe unten) auf deutsch umschalten. Entgegen der Steam-Info gibt es auch englischen Ton. Ansonsten gibts die GOG-Version aber auch standardmäßig mit allen Sprachen. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=565852222

Noch was zur Technik: ich konnte das Hauptmenu über F1 nur aufrufen, wenn ich in den Fenstermodus gewechselt bin. Das ist nicht weiter schlimm aber etwas nervig. Auch hat sich nach jedem neuen Start des Spies der Ton wieder auf englisch gestellt. Auch das war nicht weiter schlimm (Strg + T) und auch nicht, dass die Maus beim anklicken von Gegenständen oder Aktionen etwas zögerlich reagiert hat. Die Portierung auf Windows 7/Windows 10 ist wohl nicht die sauberste.

33405462.review:
No idea why this game is considered a "classic". The story is horrific, the puzzles are more tedious than challenging, and the voice acting is absolutely atrocious, delivered like it was read from a script with zero emotion.

The game starts off with a slapstick comedy bit of Indy falling through 5 stories of the campus museum. (After all, what better is Indiana Jones known for than slapstick comedy!?) 

The game has you solving ridiculous puzzles like 1) randomly clicking on people walking by a hotel to find the person you came to the city for. 2) tricking said person into thinking you're a ghost so you can steal from him. 3) In the museum you work at, combining an ancient arrowhead with a rag to use as a screwdriver because, you know, you can't just go get a screwdriver from a drawer.

The story is just one non-sequitur after non-sequitur, culiminated by an abysmal ending that leaves you wondering what the point of the whole adventure you just went on was.

The Infernal Machine, which came later, though it was action adventure rather just a pure adventure game was far superior to this.

32904477.review:
A good old fashioned Lucasarts classic that sadly still suffers a few flaws.

I remember the good old days of Lucasarts, and Fate of Atlantis was, and still is, a great entry for anyone who enjoys point and click games. Decent voice acting, good dialog, decent graphics and an intriguing plot still hold up well today.

There are a few flaws though that keep this from being a top notch game. The music and sound effects are mainly old blips and bleeps, very little atmosphere in the music, especially in the jungle scenes. The voice recordings do come off as fuzzy sounding at times, thankfully there is captioning to help keep track of what's being said. 

And there is one game breaking glitch. Upon climbing the ladder in Indy's office, it stuck in a loop of climb up, climb down, meaning I had to back up to my last save, erasing an hour's worth of play. So be sure to save before entering new rooms and trying things, especially after long dialog scenes.

Glitch and assorted cons aside, it's still a pleasure to play, with a few mind bending puzzles and several laugh out loud moments. Worth a look if you want good old fun.

Bueno que puedo decir de mi juego point and click (o aventura gráfica) favorito, una joya como ningún otro
A diferencia de muchos juegos del genero actuales, Indiana Jones fate of Atlantis si es un juego especialmente desafiante por sus puzzles y porque en este juego si puedes perder, al tomar una mala decisión el juego acaba y fin…
Pero esto es lo que lo hace tan disfrutable que tengas cuidado con tus decisiones.

Y claro este juego se disfruta más jugarlo por primera vez Y SIN GUIAS, ya que muchos “gamers” actuales en lugar de esforzarse por encontrar la solución a algo, prefieren buscar guías en internet y eso le quita el sabor a todo juego, Indiana Jones fate of Atlantis su duración puede ser 4 cuatro horas si ya sabes que hacer, como yo, que ya lo había jugado años atrás, y eso porque recordaba lo que se tenía que hacer, pero si lo juegos a ciegas y sin ayuda puede que te dure como a mí, 2 meses para pasarlo XD.

Ahora de que trata Indiana Jones fate of Atlantis?
Como su nombre lo indica es la búsqueda de nuestro arqueólogo favorito Indiana Jones, en su aventura para buscar la legendaria ciudad perdida y detener a sus mayores rivales, los nazis.

Algo que hace único a este juego de muchos point and click es que cuenta con 3 caminos, ósea que durante la mitad de tu aventura tendrás un estilo de juego diferente, así como lo llaman, el de ingenio, el cual es de resolver más puzzles solo, el de los puños no hay tantos puzzles pero si mucho combate contra nazis y el de compañero, el cual también tiene sus puzzles pero tendrás a su compañera Sophia Hapgood.
El sistema de combate veo que cambio a diferencia del original ya que aquí usas el ratón y en el original usabas el botones numérico
Otra cosa en esta versión es la inclusión de voces, ya que el original no las tenía, pero aquí si, me tengo que quejar, no por las voces si no porque parece que no siempre se sincronizan del todo bien, pero nada grave.
El juego por alguna razón viene solo en inglés, si no tienes problemas adelante, pero si quieres en español busca en google ay parches para darle los subtítulos en español (aunque les diré que la desincronización con las voces se notas más con los subtítulos en español por obvias razones).
Indiana Jones fate of Atlantis en uno de esos clásicos point and click que cualquiera amante de este género debe jugar si o si y aunque gráficamente se ve muy viejo, solo diré, a quien carajo le importa, a veces uno se divierte más con juegos así de épicos que con actuales que solo sacan juegos que gráficos realistas, que texturas, que partículas, que 4k 1080, que mi cola y su puta madre.

Mi nota
10

30419876.review:
Indiana Jones and the genre optimised by his franchise is something I've been MAJORLY obsessed with, and been a fav of mine for most of my life. I love all four films (yes, you can go f*ck yourselves other reviewers, the Crystal Skull is A LOT better than this game), copycats and stuff inpired by or in the style of him. So the premiere point-n-click game of his made back in the early 90s was something I was happily on board to experience. My impression?

Well I think an appropriate thing to call it is "The Janky Adventures of Indiana Jones". Yeah, I don't know if the developers of it could've done anything to make it less janky, but it is that at least a little. The gameplay mechanics are solid, they do a good job, but I like mine a bit smoother. They have a feeling of jaggedness and stiffness.

The voice actor who plays Dr. Jones doesn't even get close to sounding like him. I once suggested to my old man, who's a fan too, an idea I've had for a while for an Indiana Jones animated series with Harrison Ford actually stepping into a recording booth to voice him. It would be better than a fifth film, and would fix Fords age getting in the way. My pop just flat out told me that he thought Harrison wouldn't do voice work for anything. I wonder if back in the early 90s, he was in a public library or something, and saw someone playing this game on a publicly availible computer, asked what this newfangled thing on the computer was, watched a little, and then asked why Indiana Jones totally didn't sound like himself, which is how he got the opinion he told me. But it can slid do to artistic licence or medium constrants or whatever.

The tone is also slightly off. It feels like someone's close approximation of the Indiana Jones tone. I'm admittedly picky, so this caused the game/story as a whole to not feel that definitive. Not that it was bad, they tried. Stuff like the female sidekick character and the stuff she does and that happen to her, the design of the stuff in and from Atlantis, and a noticable amount of the dialogue, successfully lend to the appropriate classic tone. But when stuff like Jones dressing up like Charlie Brown on Halloween night to pretend to be a ghost, and Jones clumsily tumbling down multiple floors of his own university happen, the tone is comprimised due to out of place sillyness. I am planning to read the comic book adaption soon, so maybe that will help give me a better appreciation of the story.

The problem solving of the game is decent in the first half, but in the second half, I consistently was falling prey to mistakenly thinking the game was too strict for what turned out to be the correct solution, to be the correct solution. The game comes off as too strict for the ladder item to be usable in multiple places in Atlantis, or too strict for the knife thrower to be someone you can talk to. I guess suffering from cronic depression, the worst/hardest case scenario is the one I jump to first. But it's frustrating to go to a walkthrough, not because you don't know, but because you think you know, but you need CONFIRMATION BECAUSE THE GAME ISN'T TRUSTWORTHY AND HAS THE ATTITUDE OF A PRANKSTER.

But moving on, here's a query. Doesn't Indiana Jones get to experience a bunch of awesome things? What cool stuff do you get to do? Well my favorite thing would have to be the exploration of Atlantis itself in the form of a giant maze. You get to run Indiana Jones around a giant maze, try and find all the rooms you can enter, and avoid the Nazi soldiers. Indiana Jones and giant mazes were meant to meet each other! There are other set piece objective activites like that which give the game some substance. Flying a hot air balloon is okay, just a smidgen too hard, just to name one. 

I recommend this game, but only as a novelty piece. It deserves to be counted certainly as a solid part of the franchise because it is fun enough and Indiana Jones enough. But it has too many deviant things to it to escape novelty status in my opinion.

27073520.review:
I remember playing this when it came out. This was before I had access to Internet and I can't count how many times you got stuck on a puzzle without having Google to rescue you. Nope, you had to figure it out on your own. If you were lucky there was a monthly game magazine that had it in the "Hints and tips" section but otherwise it was up to you and your brain to find the solutions.

This might sound tedious and boring but in fact it was way more rewarding than any modern puzzle game. When you finally solved something you felt like Sherlock. Which I'm sure was the point since the game doesn't hold your hand or have any signs that says "Solution this way". You might argue that "The Dig" is more difficult, and I'm sure it was, but I didn't enjoy that as much as playing Indy. Excellent humour, excellent plot, excellent puzzles and over all one of the best games ever made. The now dated graphics is just part of the charm of this gem.

So, if you want to give your brain a little massage and give it a rest from quick time events and actually THINK for a while, pick this up. It's exactly what MYST, The 7th Guest and all the other iconic puzzle games are but it has Indy and a beatiful sense of humour.

You won't regret it.

Zusammen mit Day of the Tentacle und Monkey Island 3 streitet sich Indiana Jones and the Fate of Atlantis in meinem Kopf und Herzen seit ich denken kann um den Titel "MEIN Spiel - überhaupt und insgesamt". 
Im Grunde genommen hat immer das Spiel gerade die Nase vorn, dessen Soundtrack ich zuletzt gehört habe. Da es die älteste der drei Alternativen ist, fällt meine objektive Entscheidung jedenfalls zu seinen Gunsten aus.
Der Titel steht in meiner Wahrnehmung symbolhaft für die Hochphase der Adventures im Besonderen und die Hochphase einer gewissen, für mich nicht näher definierbaren Gaming-Popkultur im Allgemeinen.
Point and Click ist das Genre, mit dem meine Spielerkarriere angefangen hat, und das ich, auch wenn ich in Sachen Spielmechanik gar kein großer Rätsler bin, erzähltechnisch gesehen immer noch für das beste halte. Ein Vorteil ist außerdem, dass es technisch besser altert als andere Spiele aus den 90ern. Das gilt in besonderer Weise auch für Indiana Jones and the Fate of Atlantis. Es war damals alles da, was es für die Narration braucht, und das ist es auch heute noch unverändert. Kindheitserinnerung und Lebensgefühl, ein Mythos in Spieleform.

26213009.review:
[h1]This game is a 10 John Williams’ composed theme songs out of 10[/h1]

This review is a shortened reupload from [url=https://gaolioccasionallyreviews.wordpress.com/2016/06/28/indiana-jones-and-the-fate-of-atlantis/]Gao Li Occasionally Reviews[/url] due to Steam's character limits.

[b][u]NOTE:[/u][/b]
[list]
[*] The original release of [i]Indiana Jones and the Fate of Atlantis[/i] from 1992 came out in several European languages including German and French, however, these are not available in this particular release.
[*] Unlike some Point & Click adventures, this game includes Game Over screens, so save often and use different save states to not run into problems later on.
[/list]

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=448451555

[h1]The Game[/h1]
Dr. Henry Walton “Indiana” Jones Jr. PhD is an American lecturer for archaeology at Barnett College who goes on wild treasure hunting adventures whenever he’s not busy teaching. Partially based on Henry Rider Haggard’s Allan Quatermain, Dr. Jones is best known for his wit, as well as his iconic clothes: the bullwhip, the leather jacket, and the fedora. Despite being blessed with substantial knowledge on ancient cultures, languages, and combat methods, he often makes the situation worse by accidentally leading his opponents directly to the mystical treasures he tries so hard to prevent them from getting. His most prominent enemies are the Nazis who want to unearth ancient artefacts and plan to abuse them for their world dominating plans. In Indiana Jones and the Fate of Atlantis the Wehrmacht now tries to find the sunken city-state of Atlantis and is determined to kidnap Sophia Hapgood, Indy’s former partner, to reach it. Fortunately, Dr. Jones is able to get to her in time, but discovers that her apartment has already been ransacked by them. The two heroes now set out on a thrilling race to find Atlantis before the Germans can.

The game was released twice, once in 1992 and then in 2009 with a newly added voice over and reworked sound effects. Despite it bringing back Lucas Arts’ staples like the SCUMM engine, it sets itself apart from the developer’s other Point & Click adventures like The Secret of Monkey Island (1990), Day of the Tentacle (1993), or Grim Fandango (1998) by incorporating a much more versatile, partially randomized world that takes player choices into consideration. The story of The Fate of Atlantis can roughly be split into three acts, with the first and last always playing out more or less the same way, but the second offering players a choice on how they wish to proceed.

[b][u]Players can go for one of three playstyles:[/u][/b]
[list]
[*] [u]Wits[/u]
[list]
[*] By picking the “wits” route, Indy will travel alone and face a number of very difficult puzzles by himself.
[/list]
[*] [u]Fists[/u]
[list]
[*] When opting for the “fists” route, Indy still travels alone, but the amount of puzzles and their difficulty level will be greatly reduced in exchange for more hand to hand combat.
[/list]
[*] [u]Team[/u]
[list]
[*] When selecting the “team” option, Indy will be joined by Sophia and together they will try to work their way towards Atlantis.
[/list]
[/list]

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=448452679

What surprised me is that these three options not only truly alter the gameplay, but that some locations, like Algiers, will look differently, while others, like Thera, are only available in certain routes. Not only that, but depending on the playstyle, characters like Omar Al-Jabbar will change in personality. Even during the team route, one will encounter puzzles with alternative solutions to them. Both Indiana and Sophia, for example, have different ways of trying to get information from Alain Trottier in Monaco.

But the game’s strength is also its weakness. In order to add variety, item locations, puzzle solutions, and some NPC responses are randomized. This certainly adds flavor when replaying the experience, but also might make re–searching items and information somewhat tedious and demands attentiveness from players. It also means that one should keep pen and paper ready (or take screenshots) as some puzzles rely on memorizing and correctly interpreting clues. Two minor gripes I have with this game are what they pass off as German and that apart from three brief sequences, there appears to be no way to play as Sophia. After briefly playing as her at the beginning of the game, I was anticipating a tag team mechanic that never came.

Overall, I was not prepared for how hard the puzzles were going to be. This is definitely a good thing and I loved that I had to think as much as I did in this game, but players who just want to enjoy a nice story might want to think twice about purchasing a copy of The Fate of Atlantis. And despite my enjoyment for everything, when I finally thought that I had gotten the hang of things and that the game did not have any new tricks up its sleeves, act three came along and threw me for a loop with a massive fetch quest and increasingly cryptic clues. I was completely stuck and did not know how to proceed. At this point, I unfortunately have to admit that I caved in and cheated. I looked up what I needed to do on the internet and as it turns out, I had missed a barely visible cogwheel that was hanging on a wall in one room. Unfortunately, some of the plot relevant items in this game are barely visible or blend in so well with the background that players will pixel hunt to progress.

Nevertheless, the astonishingly detailed and advanced presentation of this 1992 title kept me on the edge of my seat and I couldn’t wait to see where things were going from here on out. Design–wise, the game is definitely a high-end product that will leave players guessing at how long the developers must have worked on it. Especially alluring are little details, like the waterfall in Knossos, or the pitch dark rooms that become brighter the longer Indy stays in them. However, not everything is perfectly executed. Point & Click adventures are really good at presenting inventory and dialog based puzzles, but terrible when it comes to fighting or driving mechanics. Though these are a nice change of pace from the riddles, they are somewhat unintuitive in The Fate of Atlantis. When driving through the streets of Monaco, the car is very stiff and the fighting mechanic remains to be a mystery to me.

Players can choose to either control the fights with a mouse, or, after pressing the F key, by using their keyboard. Strikes and blocks can be done to the top, mid, or lower region, and there is a way to skip most of the violent encounters by pressing the 0 key. Fortunately, the Steam version includes a pdf file of the game’s manual, explaining the intricacies of the mechanics as well as some hints for the game overall.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=448451954

[h1]Bugs[/h1]

I encountered one game breaking bug, during my third playthrough, while playing on my old toaster – an old, 32-bit desktop PC running on Windows Vista Home Premium, an Intel Core 2 CPU, an Nvidia GeForce 9500 GT, and 3070 MB RAM. There were occasional graphical bugs throughout my various playthroughs, (I replayed the game several times to see different puzzle solutions, endings, and alternate routes), but none of them dampened the fun nor are they truly worth talking about, except for this one. During my run in the “wits” route, Indy temporarily disguises himself as a German sailor. Upon changing back to his actual outfit, his whip was suddenly missing and I could not proceed with the story. It is suggested to save frequently and to use different save stages, to avoid this conundrum.

25744909.review:
In 1995, at the tender age of 12, I got my first x86 PC: a Pentium 286 16MHz (can't remember how much RAM or anything else). My father had a 486 in his office, and I'd get to play with it sometimes, but not long and not often. Still, my first gaming PC was a glorious machine for me at the time. Among the games I used to play (Master of Magic, Monkey Island, Day of the Tentacle, Sam & Max, Leisure Suit Larry, Ultima Underworld, Alone in the Dark, Doom, SimFarm, etc...), there was one LucasArts point-and-click adventure in particular that filled me with a sense of wonder and even awe: Indiana Jones and the Fate of Atlantis. I wasn't exactly a fan of Indiana Jones, but this game was bigger than the character. My English was barely rudimentary at the time, and I couldn't really follow much of the story and the humour. But the sense of wonder and awe was there from the start, and it remains to this day at the rugged age of 33, on my nth playthrough. While I do have very fond memories of all the other LucasArts adventures and other games from that period, this game will always have a special place in my memories.

In many ways, it is a classic LucasArts adventure in terms of gameplay, humour, cartoonish villains, and several tough and sometimes questionable puzzles. But all the mythology behind Atlantis, the clandestine translation of Plato's dialogue that you have to decipher, the eerie and sometimes Lovecraftian atmosphere when you finally reach the submersed city... the artists and writers who made this game were onto something here. It was and remains a unique, wonderful game.

25709353.review:
If you like the Indiana Jones series and wish to see everything that are related to his numerous adventures Worldwide, this is one of the stones that you have to tread on.  I have played and finished the 2003 Lucas Arts game Emperor's Tomb before and did not hesitate to buy this 1992 game in year 2016, once i heard that it has completely unique set of events which were not replicated in any Indy film/game before or after. I wanted to finish the game by not reading any of hints or tips from a walkthrough guide -and i succeeded-, because adventuring through the untold dullness of life is THE INHERENT core of Indy adventures. This game gives that unique feeling of being an Indiana Jones even with 1992 graphics and sounds. Because, the feeling of playing Dr. Jones does not rely on eye-candy graphics, but lies with finding whatever way to wrestle through life even if it goes somewhere that was not intended initially. 

Once the game starts, be careful about your selected words towards other people -be it an enemy, comrade, or foreigner- because it affects the storyline. If you want to hear all quotes, know that we can save our progress anytime we want. So, the game does not punish us needlessly. If you stuck at a level and not finding a proper way to go further, i recommend NOT to rush a walkthrough guide quickly. I somehow figured out many challenges by trying to act in the same manner as Harrison Ford we know. IMO, the game scenario has outdone even the well-known Indy films. All things considered, buy this game if you know and follow Indy franchise and/or want to travel in time to see what a PC game feels like in early 90's. Either way, you won't be disappointed.

25412504.review:
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Spiel: 

Indiana Jones and the Fate of Atlantis, eines Uhrgesteine des Point & Click Adventure Genre aus dem Hause LucasArts. Ein Game für Anfänger bis Pro.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Einzelspieler:

Man Spielt Indiana Jones, der sich auf die Suche nach Atlantis macht. Wie schon so oft sind natürlich die Nazis Indis Gegenspieler die auch Atlantis finden wollen. Das Game ist wie ein Film den man spielt, Rätsel, Humor und typische Indi Momente kommen wie aus den Filmen alles vor. Die Geschichte ist gut erzählt und wird nicht langweilig, Rätsel sind immer logisch und zum Schluss auch Anspruchsvoll. Man kann sterben und hat teilweise mehrere Antwortmöglichkeiten in Gesprächen, sowie kleine Änderungen im Abspann sind auch da.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Grafik:

Die Grafik ist ganz gut, für damalige Verhältnisse aber für heute etwas verpixelt (Leider übersieht man trotzdem manchmal was bei der Grafik). Wen die Grafik stört kann auch per ScummVM behelfen da man dort wirklich ein Paar gute Filter findet, die es etwas besser aussehen lassen.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Musik:

Die Musik ist wie gewohnt Typisch Indiana Jones.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Steuerung:

Die Steuerung Super, hatte keinerleih Probleme es mit Maus und Tastatur zu spielen. 

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Pro/Contra:

+ schöne Geschichte
+ Englische Sprachausgabe
+ Score am beim Beenden
+ gute Musik
+ gute Grafik
+ verschiedene Antwortmöglichkeiten 
+ anspruchsvolle Rätsel
- kein Deutscher Untertitel (kann aber gepatcht werden) http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=565852222
- keine Hilfe Funktion

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Fazit:

Ein sehr gutes Point&Click Adventure wie man es von LucasArts erwartet und kennt. Leider fehlte der Deutsche Untertitel den man aber sehr einfach nachpatchen konnte. Wieder mal ein Zeitloser Klassiker der nur etwas unter seinen Grafik leidet was aber per ScummVM etwas erträglicher wird (ich habe es ohne ScummVM durchgespielt). Ich habe 11 Stunden gebraucht um es durchzuspielen aber hatte auch des öfteren mal eine Komplettlösung parat.

Wer also eine bessere Geschichte als „Indiana Jones und das Königreich des Kristallschädels“ und den Witz und die Rätsel vom alten Indi wird hier nicht zu kurz kommen.

Für alle die es interessiert Went2Play arbeitet seit Jahren an „Indiana Jones and the Fate of Atlantis - Special Edition“ wo nun nur noch Disney ihr Ok geben muss oder die Rechte überträgen müsste.

Petition: change[dot]org/p/the-walt-disney-company-give-went2play-rights-from-disney-to-develop-a-ij-fate-of-atlantis-special-edition

http://remakeofatlantis.blogspot.de/


----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Zusammengefasst: 

Einzelspieler: 9/10
Grafik: 7/10
Musik: 8/10
Steuerung: 9/10
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Spiel: 8/10

I LOVE the original game.
The soundtrack was mystical and evoked wonder; the game's sound effects were well timed and fit the objects and actions. 

THIS -is not- that game. Someone stripped all of that away and replaced it with a poorly made midi sountrack, and almost none of the games sound effects are present.

The original title had an ambiance like no other; this re-release is a poor representation of the work of talented programmers who made an amazing title back when pixelized point and click adventures first hit the gaming world.

Don't waste your money on this digital release.
Find the original game on CD or a .zip file, and download SCUMMVirtualMachine to play it in it's high quality original format.

22716675.review:
(From my blog at fredcasdensbasement.com)

The year is 1939...


A Mr. Smith has tasked Professor Henry 'Indiana' Jones Jr, with finding a lock to match a key he happens to have... but it's all apart of plot... for Mr. Smith is Klaus Kerner of the Third Reich and they are searching for the lost City of Atlantis! This my friends is how the adventure that is Indiana Jones and the Fate of Atlantis begins....


Release in 1992 (on floppy disk and later CD-ROM with audio) from Lucas Arts, this is one of my all time favorite computer games. I have a real soft spot for the classic Lucas Arts games like this, Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade, Day of the Tentacle and Sam & Max Hit The Road, the simple but effective point and click, puzzle games were things that quite grew on me... and something I remember how to play (as you can see in the replay video of a live stream covering the first third of the game over the period of two hours while going for the 'team path')


So what is it about this game from 24 years ago that makes it worth playing? Well for one it is an Indiana Jones adventure, it has the look and feel of something grand, even if the graphics don't really convey it, the story tells it wonderfully.


There is a lot of replay value, with various dialog choices that have different reactions, plus there are three different paths, one a team path with Sophia Hapgood, one where Indy is solo and is heavy on the puzzles, and one where Indy gets into fights along the way. While each path starts and ends the same, the middle portion of the story varies.I personally prefer to Team Path, because Sophia and Indy have great chemistry as characters, and when you think about it, all the Indiana Jones films see him with a sidekick. Plus it means taking breaks for some side-conversation and getting insight on what to do.


Adding to the replay value is the 'random' factor, as if you play through the game once and play through it again with the exact same choices, some events happen slightly differently, such as herding the jungle rodent towards a snake (why did it have to be snakes) sees the rodent start off at a different point every time, the collection where the Lost Dialog of Plato is found varies not to mention the location (It could be in a wax cat, in a tipped over book case, behind a totem pole), what the shop keeper would wand in a trad for a Squab on a Stick and the combination of the Sun, Moon and World Stone can change.


And because of all these things, I think the game has aged very well and the same could be said for a lot of the Lucas Arts point and click games. It's why I hope at some point more of them get ported to Steam at some point, because these are games that should be experienced and enjoyed in this day and age.

22563067.review:
I still remember this great game on CD-ROM for our good old Windows 3.1 when we got it.  This game, to me, is the epitome of LucasArts games.

For newcomers:  This game is a classic and debatably one of LucasArts' greatest games---if not THE greatest game, according to some fans.  The story, puzzles, appropriate amount of humor, atmosphere, and replay value are up to par.  It just never gets old.  Plus (though this is personal) I always thought the puzzles and solutions in FoA made so much more sense than any of the Monkey Island series.  "Monkey wrench" anyone???  Anyway, at first glance it will no doubt feel ancient for the current generation---Aesthetically it is very outdated and has aged badly---.  If, though, you can get over that part and appreciate the artistic/entertainment quality of the game, you will most certainly be glad to have experienced this game.  I still don't know why they made a HD remake of Monkey Island but not for Fate of Atlantis.

For those who played the old version:  While some remember the game before it had the voice talents, I was introduced to the version with voice actors.  So this is no problem to me.  In fact, it wouldn't be the same without the voices to me.  The only flaw in the Steam version is that the music is very different from the original.  The music is the same as far as score goes (I think), but the quality is different.  It sounds more digital and cheap.  For someone like myself who really enjoyed the sound/audio of the original, this sole flaw is a huge one.  Needless to say, the game is still great.

Very few of these classic games aged well, thankfully this one did; there are a couple minor dialogue parts missing, but other than that it's just like how I remember.  It's one of the few 8-bit strategy point & click games that can be played over and over, and never get old.

21263059.review:
Il est probablement un des tout meilleurs exemples de point & click des années 1990 et s'il reste encore très agréable à jouer aujourd'hui, ce jeu daté de 1992 pourrait déplaire aux allergiques aux pixels de cette époque. Mais ça serait sans doute bien dommage.

Dès le générique du début, on est directement emmené dans l'univers d'Indiana Jones avec son thème musical bien connu, son humour et un début d'action. Les références aux films est d'ailleurs fréquente durant tout le jeu. On a droit à l'humour sarcastique, à la camarade féminine, aux voyages exotiques, aux références historiques et mythologiques et aux nazis toujours autant méchants qu'idiots.
On retrouve au bas de l'écran l'inventaire et le tableau des actions à sélectionner typique des jeux LucasArts. Sur l'écran de jeu, l'action par défaut est "marcher vers" et "regarder" quand on est sur l'inventaire. Bien pratique et amplement suffisant pour surmonter les limites de l'affichage. L'image reste agréable à part ça grâce aux décors variés et riche en détails. Le son se limite à la musique et à quelques bruitages. Les dialogues sont uniquement écrits, sauf dans la version Steam (mais uniquement en anglais).

On pourra regretter certains phases de jeu moins intéressantes, les scènes de combat à base de clics inutiles (il y a heureusement toujours moyen d'éviter l'affrontement), des énigmes bien corsées et quelques imprécisions.

Le jeu est notamment disponible sur Steam (mais nécessite un patch pour avoir les textes en français) et sur GOG (version entièrement française) à tout petit prix.
Attention, ne pas confondre ce jeu avec le jeu d'action sorti la même année et qui porte (pratiquement) le même nom.

Au final, les amateurs de point & click et les fans d'Indiana Jones y trouveront assurément leur compte.

Я постараюсь сейчас подобрать все плюсы и минусы игры.
Плюсы.
1) Головоломки. И это один из самых главных плюсов игры. Они тяжелы, и тут не хватит просто го кликанья по экрану как в других играх. Все ответы храняться в диалогах (ну почти во всех но в 90 случаях именно так). В общем заставят подумать.
2) Юмор. Одним из главных плюсов фильмов об Индиане Джонс был юмор. И тут он сохранён. Вспомните начальный уровень в Нью Йорке где Инди должен был поговорить с Софией и привлёк её внимание куклой. 1) Никаких изменений. То есть. Экран 640 на 900 или даже меньше и вполне логично что бы в стимовском издании разрешили менять разрешение но нет нельзя. 20348021.review:
Disclaimer: No refrigerators were nuked during the playing or reviewing of this game. 

This game was great! The game looks great, for a classic LucasArt adventure game, and the voice acting is actually pretty spot on.  The puzzles can be a bit challenging, but luckily there isn't a moment where you have to start the game over because you didn't get that one item you were supposed to get in the last section (Shame on you, Last Crusade). Also, there are three different paths to beat this game: the Team Path, The Wits Path, or The Fists Path. I personally chose the Team Path, because then the puzzles aren't too demanding, since you have help, and you don't have to worry about the fighting system. Also, Indy has to have his lady :). The fighting system is greatly improved from Indy's Last Crusade, but thats really not saying much, since it couldn't have gotten worse. Not only are there multiple ways to accomplish tasks, but there are two different endings, depending on what kind of Indy you want to be. Overrall, this was a great game, that I know I will play again for the different paths. OH, and different paths mean visiting different locations! 
Honestly, this should have been the fourth movie. They would have to have tweaked it just a bit, but this should have been the film. The love/hate relationship between Indy and Sophia is real and genuine (I loved seeing Indy grab her for that "we saved the world from the Nazis kiss"). Also, its Indy against the Nazis, the ones we love to see him fight. The script is strong and believable.  Just a fun great game that all adventure gamers should pick up, at any cost.

UPDATE: My play time is not accurate, since I played this game on the SCUMM engine. I used my Steam file and loaded it to SCUMM, which greatly improves how it looks and sounds. My overrall playtime would be between 6-7 hours for a first time.

This might be my nostalgia speaking, but to me this will forever be the TRUE Indiana Jones 4.

If you have any interest in Indy, you have to play this game. The plot, the mystery mixing history and mysticism, the nice touches of humor, the nazi villains, some nice action and twists... Arguably, it is sometimes even more "Indiana Jones" than the original trilogy movies themselves! 

This game also has a pretty unique feature for a retro adventure game : the story actually branches at one point, giving you very different playthroughs. Some puzzles are also randomized. This helps replayability a lot.

Bearing with the old graphics of this game is entirely worth it. Unless you truly can't stand seeing some pixels, the dated technology should not stop you from enjoying a true Indiana Jones adventure.

If you read this, you care about the Indy franchise, don't you? Then just play this. You won't regret it.

I've must have finished Indy 4 about 20 times by now. Pretty much once every year. I've been playing since not long after it's release on my trusty old IBM 286. Hard drive was so small I had to choose between Windows 3.1 or Indy. So My Windows days pretty much started with 95... ;)

Anyway, you are Doctor Henry "Indiana" Jones Jr. And as the title suggests, you're trying to find Atlantis before the Nazi's do. This is one of the best stories written for a game, in my opninion. A couple of hours into the game, you get to choose in which way you'll tackle the game. You can do it together with your 'partner in crime', Sophia Hapgood, or you can think your way through, or fight. This adds a lot of replay value.

If it's not on sale, it's a really good deal. Especially in a bundle with Last Crusade, Loom and The Dig. Last Crusade and Loom have never really been to my liking, but the Dig is also really worth it. With the help of Steven Spielberg, they've created another wonderfull classic adventure game.
When it's on sale, it's really a no brainer. For less than a buck and a couple of cents you have a lot of quality gamplay!

The Steam version is not the best. The MIDI table they use in the emulator (haven't really looked into what it runs on), is God-awful. But you can just run it through SCUMMVM, and this works so well and easy. Also, you can play it on your smartphone through SCUMMVM, which I've done for my last playthrough of nearly all Lucasarts adventures.

Anyway, what are you still doing reading this!? Grab your whip and hat and travel all over the world to unravel the fate of Atlantis! Godspeed!

This is an all time classic that I loved as a little kid in the 90s growing up with floppy disks and pixel graphics, and the first time booting it up took me back.

Fate of Atlantis follows the same design of Monkey Island that requires a user to talk, build, and combine items in zany combinations to crack puzzles and advance the story. This is not a combat game per say aside from fist fighting and requires players to use their wits. Sadly this type of game has become lost with the ages, which is a shame because the dialogue based puzzle games really are an outstanding genre.

The graphics are exactly as they were when the game was first produced, as well as the sound...which is as it should be. Indiana Jones requires no editing or touch ups as the game itself wins anyone over with its story and puzzles that will make even the most clever player frustrated. This is a difficult game that I dare anyone to beat without the guide in a decent amount of time.

18699231.review:
I first played this game as a child, at the start of the adventure game craze.  I bought it on Steam because of the fond memories I have of playing it back then, and it's always been my favorite Lucas Arts title.  Being an adventure game, the pace is usually whatever you happen to play it as.  In addition, it was one of the earlier popular titles that featured a choice of play styles- one can choose fairly early on to play the puzzle, teamwork, or action pathways.
There are some things to poke holes in it.  The graphics are clearly from the early 90s and haven't held up as well as I'd hoped, although they are still servicable.  Some of the backgrounds are actually quite well done and it's only in detailed images that the quality is lacking.  In addition, the voice acting is not that good.  Since the subtitles are defaulted to on, though, one can simply put on some music and mute the actual game.
The biggest problem is that the controls on the Steam version don't work as well as those in the original version.  Since most of the time, you're simply going to be pointing and clicking, it doesn't make much difference.  However, fight sequences (which are much more common on the action pathway) may be difficult until you get the hang of the odd control scheme.
Those issues aside, the story is comparable to the movies (and better than Crystal Skull).  Most players will likely be able to complete a playthrough in several hours, but there is a save game feature should you need multiple sittings.  This is a fun game that all adventure game fans should at least try out.

17629924.review:
Indiana Jones and the Fate of Atlantis ist eines der (wenn nicht sogar DAS) beliebteste Point and Click-Adventure aller Zeiten (und Gamer)! Die Liebe und der Hype um dieses Spiel gehen sogar so weit das viele Indiana Jones-Fans sich lieber das als vierten Film gewünscht hätten, als den den wir dann letztendlich bekommen haben. 
Ich für meinen Teil zähle nicht zu den Leuten die diese Meinung vertreten und hier ist warum: Ich finde das sich dieses Spiel nicht wirklich nach einem Indiana Jones Abenteuer anfühlt, geschweige denn das der Charakter des Doktor Jones selbst, gut rübergebracht wurde. Das ganze Spiel lang hatte ich nie das Gefühl den Mann auf seinen Abenteuern zu begleiten den ich aus den (von mir heißgeliebten) Filmen kenne, sondern den Indy den wir bekommen hätten wenn Tom Selleck den Part ergattert hätte...

Nicht falsch verstehen...ich mag Tom Selleck.

Auch hatte ich ehrlich gesagt nicht das Gefühl mich auf einem Abenteuer zu befinden, sondern eher in einer großen Old-School-Rätselkiste.
Und hier ist der Clu an der Sache...

Für alle die bis hierher gelesen haben und sich nicht abgewendet haben weil der Typ hier ihr Lieblingsgame kritisiert, kommt jetzt der Grund warum ich dieses Spiel trotzdem wärmstens weiterempfehlen kann...wenn auch mit Einschränkungen.

Es IST nunmal eine ziemlich gute Old-School-Rätselkiste. Ich habe zwar nur selten das Gefühl ein Indiana Jones Abenteuer zu spielen (weshalb ich den 4ten Film auch weiterhin verteidige, weil Story und Setting perfekt in die 50-iger passen und ich keinen Groll gegen Shia LaBeouf hege) aber das fantastische Gefühl nach stundenlangem Überlegen und Rumprobieren endlich auf des Rätsels Lösung zu kommen ist unvergleichlich!

Das Spiel ist von 1992 und nutzt seinen 8-Bit Grafikstil super aus, alles wirkt immer noch detailliert und interessant, auch die Animationen sind ziemlich gut, ich wünschte mir nur manchmal Indy könnte durch einen Doppelklick schneller laufen, weil die Wege auf den Screens schon recht lang sind, vorallem wenn man endlich weiß wie man ein Rätsel zu lösen hat, aber Stunden braucht um hinzukommen.

Die Musik ist auch ziemlich gut und entwickelt sich glücklicherweise, durch kleine Pausen,  nie zu einem nervigen Daurgedudel.

Die Sprecher machen ihre Sache gut, auch wenn die Tonabmischung wesentlich besser hätte sein können, zumal sie den Text sicher in einem Tonstudio aufgenommen haben. Nur der unpassend dunkelklingende Sprecher von Indy unterstreicht noch das Gefühl nicht den echten Mann mit Hut und Peitsche vor sich zu haben.

Die Story ist Indiana Jones-typisch simpel: Indy muss vor den Nazis Atlantis erreichen. 
Passt gut in die Reihe, entwickelt sich aber (leider) nie zu einem wirklich spannenden Thrillride so wie die Filme und das gelegentlich plötzliche Auftauchen der Nazis ist zwar jedes mal überraschend aber nie Spannend, weil man während den Zwischensequenzen sowieso nie in die Action eingreifen kann.

Nun zu Indys diesmaliger Begleiterin: Sophia Hapgood.
Als Indy-Fan habe ich schon von kleinauf, viel von diesem Game gehört, aber am meisten von Miss Hapgood, die von vielen Retrogame-Fans, Spielezeitschriften, Onlinemagazinen und Internet-Critics als der großartigste Sidecharacter/ die großartigste weibliche Videospielcharakterin aller Zeiten gekührt wird.

Aber warum? Ich versteh wirklich nicht was alle an ihr finden: 
1.Sie gibt das ganze Spiel lang nur Wiederworte und zwar nicht von der charmanten "i´m a independent Woman"- Sorte 
2. Zu jedem noch so unwichtigen Scheiß muss man sie überreden, oder gar zwingen 
3. und sie wird öfter gefangen genommen, um von mir gerettet zu werden, als jeder andere Indiana Jones-Sidekick. 

Ausserdem (ich weiß nicht ob es an der Sprecherin, oder der visuellen Umsetzung liegt) wenn sie im Game über "Nur-Ab-Sal" palavert und eine "Seance" abhält, wirkt das immer unfassbar nervig und aufgesetzt.

Zum Thema Gefangennahme, gibt es sogar ganze Stellen im Spiel die quasi aus Jäger des verlorenen Schatzes rauskopiert wurden. 
!SPOILER! Sophia wird gefangen genommen und auf ein U-Boot verfrachtet (wie Marion Ravenwood), Indy muss sich aus einem Untergrundgewölbe rausschaufeln um sie zu befreien (wie im Film nur diesmal alleine), Indy klettert unbemerkt auf/in das U-Boot um sie zu Retten und den Nazis folgen zu können und am Ende (wenn man sich gut anstellt) stehen beide daneben, während die Bösen explodieren, oder so ähnlich. !SPOILER ENDE!
Ich meine selbst Shia LaBeouf hat wenigstens mal einen coolen Fechtkampf auf einem fahrenden Truck, also bitte!

Es ist definitiv nicht so schlimm wie es klingt und ich hasse sie auch nicht oder ähnliches, genausowenig wie das Spiel an sich...ich verstehe nur diesen abnormen Hype nicht. 

Fazit: Indiana Jones and the Fate of Atlantis ist ein gutes und intelligentes Point and Click-Adventure. Es hat zwar meiner Meinung nach wenig von dem was die Indiana Jones Abenteuer so großartig macht, aber als reines Spiel ist es hervorragend.

(Diese Empfehlung gilt allerdings nur für Spieler die bereits Erfahrung in diesem Old-School-Genre gesammelt haben, weil das Spiel keinerlei Hilfestellung leistet, an welche sich die meisten modernen "Gamer" bereits gewöhnt haben und man verdammt viel ausprobieren muss, ob es gerade Sinn macht oder nicht)

16842482.review:
[h1] Indiana Jones and the Fate of Atlantis [/h1]

[i]Denkt beim Rätsel lösen an Indys Worte: "Keine Ahnung. Das werd ich mir unterwegs überlegen."[/i]

[b]Einleitung:[/b]
Herrlich, nach 15 Jahren dieses Schmuckstück wieder durchgespielt zu haben. Ich habe die alten klassischen Point and Click Adventure von LucasArts vermisst. Die Story ist reine Fiktion und wurde nie verfilmt, besser als der " Kristallschädel" wäre sie auf jeden Fall geworden. *hust*

[b]Handlung:[/b] 
Wir sind der gefeierte Archäologe und Titelheld Indiana Jones. Uns fällt in den Archiven einer amerikanischen Universität, durch einen Auftrag, eine seltsame Statue in die Hände. Diese kann historisch nicht zugeordnet werden. Wir bekommen kurze Zeit später in unserem Büro, Besuch von einer "Herrn Smith", der sich als Spion des Dritten Reiches entpuppt und mit der Statue flüchtet. Wir müssen den bösen Nazi Kerner verfolgen. Durch Hinweise ensteht eine Verbindung mit Sophia Hapgood, unsere ehemalige Geliebte und Assistentin, die Vorlesungen zum Mythos Atlantis hält. Gemeinsam gehen wir auf die Abenteuerreise um den Mythos Atlantis ein für alle Mal zu enschlüsseln und den Nazis das Handwerk zu legen. Diese wollen durch einen bestimmten Rohstoff Bomben herstellen und die Weltherrschaft an sich reißen.

[b]Grafik:[/b] 
nostalgisch, gute Augen können die einzelnen Pixel sogar noch sehen! Hoffen wir mal, dass in naher Zukunft ein Remake erscheint. Die Grafik ist in diesen Kontext eher zweitrangig, es ist das Drumherum.

[b]Optional:[/b] 
Viele Wege führen bekanntlich zum Ziel und Endbildschirm, in Fate of Atlantis habt ihr drei Pfade zur Auswahl. Direkt nach Platos Dialog könnt ihr euren Weg wählen. So macht auch das mehrmalige durchspielen noch Spaß und motiviert. Jeder Weg hat einen anderen Schwerpunkt, indem er verschiedene Orte und Rätsel aufzeigt:
1) Team-Pfad
2) Denk- Pfad
3) Rätsel-Pfad

[b]Fazit:[/b]
Wer sich mit Monkey Island, Day of Tentacle, Grim Fandago und anderen Klassikern jener Zeit indentifizieren konnte, der sollte zuschlagen, weil die Rätsel Spaß machen und Indy immer einen witzigen Kommentar auf Lager hat.

If you have never played Indiana Jones and the Fate of Atlantis, but you do enjoy the point-and-click adventure games of old, you owe it to yourself to play this one.

In typical Lucasarts Adventure game fashion, there is humor spread throughout this great journey where twists and turns are abound. Even better, the entire game is voice acted, and the environments and locales you will travel to are varied and colourful. The puzzles and solutions are generally smart and not too arbitrary, and it really feels like an Indiana Jones adventure. There is also replayability added in the mix, as there are three "paths" you can play through that completely changes the puzzles and interactions you will face throughout the course of the game.

However, this is a port of the old DOS game. This means, that the resolution is very tiny, and if you can't accept the pixellation that comes with trying to stretch the image, then that is unfortunate. However, don't let the old visuals, which still looks decent due to it's stylized form, detract you from going on an incredible adventure across the world!

7/10 "Good"

14659601.review:
Indiana Jones and the Fate of Atlantis is a rather unusual entry in the SCUMM games catalogue. For a start, it's one of the few to be based around an existing IP rather than an original story. Secondly,  the game scores you as you play, with an "Indy Quotient". Granted it's meaningless, but it's interesting nonetheless...

Lucasarts has already made games based around the first three Indy films, so when there was call for another game, rather than wait for another film to make an appearance, they decided to make their own. And it's good. really good. If this game's story had been made into a film, it would have been... well... let's say somewhere below "Last Crusade" but above "Temple of Doom"

Even before the opening credits start you can tell the amount of care that has gone into this game. The word "cinematic" may keep appearing in your mind, as the first few puzzles weave their way in and around of the credits. This game is simply a joy to play.

There is one point in this game (well, technically two) where you are given the option to determine how you want to play the game. You can play it as a standard graphical adventure (WITS path), as a graphical adventure with beat-em-up subgames instead of some of the puzzles (FISTS path), or as a graphical adventure but with commentary and assistance from the game, making it a little more like an interactive movie (TEAM path). It's nice to have these options, as the puzzles and dialogue change accordingly, so it's worth playing through again.

If you like other Lucasarts adventure games, you certainly can't go wrong with this. It's more enjoyable than "Kingdom of the Crystal Skulls" anyway...

A terrific Indy puzzle game (ha ha).

Fate of Atlantis was surprisingly innovative for it's time: multiple paths through the story, an actually forgiving/signposted death system (coming from the notorious Sierra-era of instant-kills that required hours of replaying, this is a pleasant change), and Indy's voice actor actually sounds like Harrison Ford. Funny and full of charm, Fate of Atlantis feels like what it is: a classic Indiana Jones adventure.

10165285.review:
Ho giocato per la prima volta questo splendido targata LucasArts nel 1993: I PC iniziavano ad arrivare in tutte le case e le avventure grafiche mosse dal mitico motore SCUMM spopolavano su i monitor di tutto il mondo. La fatica fatta per completare questo gioco senza alcun tipo di aiuto mi è rimasta ben impressa nella mente, così come la soddisfazione per esserci arrivato in fondo. Ad oggi per quel che mi riguarda è ancora uno dei migliori titoli del genere ed incarna perfettamente tutto quello che cerco in una AG: Il Mistero, l'Esplorazione e l'Avventura.

Indiana Jones and the Fate of Atlantis è una avventura grafica, del tipo "punta e clicca", ovvero, il gioco consiste in una serie di puzzle da risolvere usando l'ingegno, i dialoghi con gli NPC e gli oggetti sparsi per le varie locations del gioco. Non starò a fare un riassunto della storia, mi limito solo a dire che vedremo Indy, assieme alla sensitiva Sophia Hapgood alla ricerca della mitica città perduta descritta da Platone, ovviamente inseguiti dai Nazisti, che vogliono impadronirsi dei segreti celati fra le sue rovine per costruire l'arma definitiva e portate in 3zo reich alla conquista del mondo.

Il gioco presenta alcune caratteristiche interessanti, tra cui l'intro giocabile: In pratica tra un titolo di testa ed un altro potremo controlare Indy alle prese con una bizzarra avventura all'interno delle sale del Barnett College. Tutto ciò è un modo molto originale di implementare un tutorial per il gioco.

L'avventura è divisa in 3 capitoli, di cui il secondo può essere giocato in ben 3 "percosi" diversi, a seconda della scelta che il giocatore farà alla fine del primo capitolo: Ingegno (dove i puzzle fanno da padrone), Azione (Indy sarà chiamo frequentemente a combattere) e Squadra (in cui si dovrà collaborare con Sophia per venire a capo degli enigmi). Inoltre, molti dei puzzle del primo e del terzo capitolo cambiano da partita a partita, rendendo quini il titolo estremamente rigiocabile.

Soffermiamoci un attimo su i puzzle del gioco: Come ho gia' detto in genere si risolvono utilizzando e/o combinandi fra loro gli oggetti che si trovano lungo il percorso o indovinando la giusta sequenza di linee di dialogo quando si parla con un NPC. Va pero' detto che non sempre la sequenza è facilmente intuibile e non aspettatevi alcun tipo di aiuto da parte del gioco, o meglio: Gli aiuti spesso ci sono sotto forma di elementi dei fondali del gioco o di testo su libri e note.

Il gioco in sostanza mette il giocatore di fronte alla necessità di pensare e sperimentare, spesso anche a tirare ad indovinare come poter aprire una porta o attivare un certo dispositivo. Qusta del resto era la moda del tempo (si parla del 1992), dai giocatori ci si aspettava dedizione e intraprendenza.

Ne consegue che Indiana Jones and the Fate of Atlantis non è un gioco facile, ne adatto a chiunque, o per lo meno non è adatto a chi non è disposto a sbattere la testa contro enigmi all'apparenza senza soluzione logica.

Detto questo però il gioco merita sicuramentela vostra attenzione se siete appassionati del genere, di cui è una delle indiscusse pietre milari.

9946827.review:
I used to play this game when I was a kid. Back then, I relied heavily on the Hint Book that came with the CD; then again, I was also 8 years old. 

There are 3 paths that one can "choose" from based on early actions and dialogue in the game: The Fists Path, the Team Path, and the Wits Path. My favorite of these three is the Team Path, simply because it seems to provide situations privy to having the largest amount of sarcastic dialogue classic to the Indiana Jones franchise. It's the only path where Sophia Hapgood (the female character) joins you for the entire time, and thus gives you an AI teammate (who has a witty demeanor quite similar to that of Marion Ravenwood).

I always feel like dialogue is the most enjoyable part of a point and click style game - especially the old DOS ones - and can definitely make or break it. This is one of my favorite games for this reason; it does a very good job staying true to the feel of the movies and really deserves it's unnoficial title of Indiana Jones 4.

If you're looking for a fast paced adventure game, this is not it. While a lot of the puzzler-type aspects can be very difficult without the use of the Hint Guide (obviously not included on Steam), fighting is optional and with the limited point-click method - not very engaging, so I wouldn't reccomend that. The puzzler aspects include using objects with one another from multiple locations and working out persuasive dialogue paths.

All in all, I would have given this game an 9/10 in the late 90's, but as it is 2014, (but I'm still nastalgic) I'd say it's a 8/10 (mostly because the DOS-style pixilizated art now drives me nuts).

9571926.review:
To start off, I'm a HUGE Indiana Jones fan! Much like Point 'n Click games, I have a love-hate relationship with Indiana Jones. I love the movies, but hate the video games. Out of all the Indiana Jones games I've played, this and Staff of Kings were the only good ones. Coincidentally, I first played through Fate of Atlantis as part of the Wii version of Staff of Kings

The game captures the wonder and sense of discovery that the films have, and combine them with the quirkiness and lovable charm of other LucasArts Point 'n Click games (Monkey Island, Sam & Max, etc.). The iMuse music system is solid, giving ambient tone and texture to every area. The voice cast is great, featuring LucasArts veterans like Nick Jameson. Doug Lee does a great job as Indy, though his voice could be a better impression of him. 

The game play is your standard affair of pointing at stuff and clicking on said stuff to solve puzzles. While fun and well paced, the game suffers from the problem that afflicts all early Point 'n Click games. Every puzzle has one and only one solution. I understand that this is likely to prevent logical fallacies and game killing bugs, but some of the puzzle solutions are so obscure and strange that it borders on the completely frustrating. When it comes to difficulty in games, there's a magical "butter-zone" where the game is frustrating enough to taunt you, but not so frustrating as to make you rage quit. You know a game is in that magical zone when you want to beat the game to teach it a lesson. This game (as well as other Point 'n Click games) has a hard time finding that "butter-zone" due to its slow pacing, but it comes closer than other games like Uninvited and Deja Vu. 

If you love Point 'n Click games or Indiana Jones, this game is worth every penny if you can get past the vices of difficult puzzles and slow pacing. Overall, the game is solid, though it's not a game you should sit down and play casually. Fate of Atlantis is a game you need to be committed to in order to play.

9412057.review:
I grew up playing this game on my first Macintosh System 7 I believe, so expect nostalgia goggles.  Fate of Atlantis is a point and click adventure game originally released in 1992 by LucasArts.

The story and atmosphere are on par with the best of the Indiana Jones movies.  While the pixelated visuals are quite dated by today's standards I find I'm still so easily immersed into the game that I hardly notice.  The voice acting was well done in the original, and it sounds like the audio quality might be better in this Steam release. The music is also dated digital sequences, but still good enough to hold the immersion and also sounds as if it's been improved.

Unlike many adventure games, there's a point where the story can take one of three routes: team up with Sophia, use your wits, or use your fists.  Each branch takes the story in a different direction and to different locations, often not accessable in the other branches.  Kids used to spread rumors of a different ending as well, but to my knowlege, no such thing exists.  The mechanics are based on selecting one of the nine pre-selected verbs and clicking something in the world that you want to act that verb upon; for example, Using "Pick Up" on "Ancient Artifact".

If you love point and click adventure games, and somehow passed this one by, I'd say you're in for a treat as Fate of Atlantis is one of the best, if not THE best.  Yeah, I went there.

For starters, I was not born around the time of old point and click adventures like LucasArts', but i would imagine that many people played them. why? Because LucasArts made what are quite possibly the best story driven point and click games. Where to begin? The graphics are as they were 20 years ago, and yet they still feel fresh, so nostalgia will hit hard with older gamers. I have not played the original, so I am not sure if this version is different in any way, but it has the original music, voice acting and graphics, so I assume it's the same. Even though i was born around the time where they started moving on to making more Star Wars games (which were mostly good, and one of them is one of my most favourite games of all time), I still wanted to try these. Last year, I saw a show with a segment about LucasArts' history, and they talked about games like Loom, Indiana Jones And the Fate Of Atlantis, Full Throttle, The Secret Of Monkey Island and many more. And I always like games with a big focus on story lines, and I decided to try them since it would be a break from Call Of Judy or whatever generic shooters are called these days. So I found a bundle with a few of LucasArts' games, and while the controls are a bit fiddly at first, I think Loom, The Dig and Indiana Jones and the Fate of Atlantis will keep me playing 'till the credits roll because of the stories that just make you reflect after the end. It's like reading a book, you say you will read one chapter, and then you read the whole book. It's games like these that make me wish I was born in 1990. Nowadays it's all about pwning n00bs in halozone with masterchef or something. Sorry for the long review about me saying how much i like the stories in these games, But after all, the one thing that sticks around in your mind about a game, is it's story. Thank you for reading.

Edit: Another thing about their games, is that the writing is so good, It's always full of humour.
