9164199.review:
With a personal nostalgia factor through the roof, you may want to take this review with a grain of salt. But I freaking love this game. Such a smart, exciting game to play with witty dialog and inspired locations. Definitley an old school vibe, which I am assuming you're looking for if you are reading this in the first place. Look no further. I'd play a game like this in heartbeat if LucasArts, SCUMM, or anyone kept producing them. 
     Anyways, there *are* two major concerns for anyone wondering (this is my attempt at writing an unbiased review). One is the voice acting, which I didn't remember from my floppy disk copies when I was a kid. But you can mute them, or better yet laugh at the horribly outrageous "German" and "French" accents. Perhaps the worst are the "Arabic" accents although I confess I only heard one, cringed too hard at the delivery, and promptly muted the voice volume in the preferences section, whish I was relieved to find was possible because the background music is a definate selling point (especially the syncopated Indiana Jones theme, somewhat Atari-fied like it belongs in a pokemon game). The other main problem is the fighting mechanism, which is complicated, or, rather, just not fun.
     Anyway, plenty of puzzles, hours of gametime, total replayability (hell, I for one attest to fifteen-years-later replayability). Please play this with your young son. Haven't even mentioned THREE DIFFERENT storylines to make it to Atlantis, with varying character allegiances, settings, and of course puzzles. Still haven't mentioned the art direction, perhaps the most understated selling point I've found when reading the other reviews. And multiple endings depending on prior actions once you make it to Atlantis. Refreshing alternative to the brainless droll of shooter games that seem to dominate the market (not that there's anything wrong with brainless droll). What happened to point and click adventure games? In a way they are to my generation as the Saturday Morning Matinee serials that inspired Dr. Jones in the first place, lost to an earlier period but their appeal lingers. And and Indiana Jones adventure is the perfect fit for this genre. Campy, but in a unique and exciting way. Plot twists a plenty. Sigh, writing this makes me want to explore the Labyrynth of Minos again. Bye.

7921812.review:
I remember this being one of the first games I ever played, albeit when I was a kid I didn't get all the references, and some of the puzzles were a little above me- but a classic point-and-click puzzle adventure game. This game did a good job with the music score, and voice acting as well as having decent graphics for its time. Some of the puzzles are challenging, and some of the controlls in can be hard to figure out in certain puzzles (e.g. the hot air ballon). This however in my opinion, in no way diminishes the story or the excement that you will get when you're trying to figure out the proper thing to say in the middle of a seance! It of course has Indy's classic humor with banter between Sophia Hapgood (don't think she's in any of the movies) and Marcus and some of the other characters that we're familiar with. Love some of the available dialogue options, they can be funny at times, as well as down-right get you into trouble! 

It is clear that the writers put a lot of thought and attention into ancient Atlantian mythology, and that is a plus. They detail excerpts from Plato and other ancient philosophers and theorize on supposed ways to find Atlantis. You will enjoy the dialoge, the score, the puzzles, and the action that is packed into this game, I recommend a try.

7749174.review:
Mittlerweile ist das Spiel mehr als zwei Jahrzehnte alt, für mich ist es aber immer noch das beste Adventure-Game das ich je gespielt habe. Wer die ersten beiden Monkey Island-Spiele oder Day of the Tentacle mochte und auch ein Fan der Indiana Jones-Filme ist, kann mit dem Spiel einfach nichts falsch machen.

Anders als der Vorgänger, das praktisch eine spielbare Version des dritten Indy-Films ist, gibt es bei diesem Adventure eine komplett eigene Geschichte. Nach ein paar Spielminuten kann man sich für drei verschiedene Wege entscheiden, einen den man zusammen mit einer Parterin bestreitet, einen Action-orientierten Weg und einen mit mehr Puzzle-Elementen. 

Man besucht in allen Versionen die selben Schauplätze und muss auch ähnliche Rätsel meistern, die Lösungswege sind aber meist verschieden und bietet damit einen gewissen Wiederspielwert.

Die Puzzles selbst sind typisch für LucasArts-Games aus der Zeit und bei einigen muss man auch wirklich das Hirn einschalten. Es gibt kein Hinweis- oder Hilfssystem, mit etwas Nachdenken sind aber alle Rätsel zu schaffen. 

Man könnte jetzt noch viel dazu schreiben, aber ich würde es mit folgenden Satz zusammenfassen: Die Geschichte und Aufmachung des Adventures hätte damals locker das Zeug dazu gehabt als Vorlage für einen echten vierten Indiana Jones-Film zu dienen.

However, this game cleverly adds voice-overs to what would normally be a text based graphical adventure, which was new at that time. This game is fun and engaging until the last few stages of the game, where the puzzles get much more complex and vague. A few times I was frustrated with the lack of leads I was given in this game in order to complete the puzzles, and much time is spent walking back and forth just to transfer items to and from your inventory. All in all a good game, but if you're a fan of this genre, or LucasArts, or adventure games, or all of them, I would recommend the Monkey Island series over this.

1995517.review:
This game is what I would consider "The fourth movie in the series", completely disregarding the trash that is Kingdom of the Crystal Skull.
It uses the classic SCUMM engine and plays similar to a monkey island game, but with a much more cinematic feel to it.
Depending on your playstyle, there are THREE different paths you can take to finish the game. The "wits" path has more puzzle solving, the "team" path is puzzle solving with a twist of teamwork and dialogue, and the fists path gets you more face-mashing Indy-Action, without being constant waves of baddies.

If you're a fan of classic Monkey Island AND Indiana Jones then look no further.

1042598.review: Pretty much the epitome of what a great point-and-click adventure game should be. Clever puzzles, three ways to play (the paths of wits, fists, and the team path), a well-written story, good artwork, good acting, good humor, and Indiana Jones...  what's not to love?

259406.review: Probably the third best Indiana Jones story, behind Last Crusade and Raiders of the Lost Ark.  It has the right balance between humor and story you expect from an Indiana Jones adventure and translates really well into an adventure game thanks to LucasArts.  Highly recommended.

523619.review:
Yeah, it's not looking like games from today. But this game is one of the first I've played on PC... and I have memories of being stuck in the damn desert and of that damn balloon to lead... When you're only a child, it's marking you. Without that game, I wouldn't be playing adventure games or indie games like Ben Jordan, Chzo Mythos or Barn Runner.

As it's a very old game, you have that old interface with "Push", "Pull", "Use", etc.. It's perhaps a weird way to play an adventure game now but it was the norm back then.

Anyway, I managed to get stuck in the first level when I remember clearly being at ease when I was a child.

The graphics are maybe pixelated but between libraries, islands, deserts and I don't know more because I stayed stuck in the desert like before and because I'm more aware of the multiple paths you can take now than before.

So, if you're in for good memories, the game is made for you.
